title: HTML Basics
description: Master HTML - the backbone of the web - from basic tags to semantic structure and forms.

lessons.title: HTML Structure & Tags
lessons.content: Learn the building blocks of every web page: elements, attributes, and document structure
details: Every HTML document starts with <!DOCTYPE html> to declare it as HTML5.
The root element is <html>, which contains two children: <head> and <body>.
<body> holds all visible content: headings, paragraphs, images, and links.

HTML tags usually come in pairs - an opening tag

and a closing tag

.
Attributes add extra information: Link - href is an attribute.
Hint: In the game, the correct tag for the largest heading is <h1>. HTML has six heading levels: <h1> (biggest) to <h6> (smallest).
lessons.example_code:
Hello World

Welcome to HTML.
key_points: Most tags need an opening and closing tag
Attributes go inside the opening tag

game.question: Choose the correct tag for the most important (largest) heading

lessons.title: Links, Images & Lists
lessons.content: Connect pages with links, display images, and organize content with lists
details: The tag creates hyperlinks: Click me.
Use target='_blank' to open a link in a new tab: <a href='url' target='_blank'>.
The tag is self-closing and needs src and alt attributes: .
alt text improves accessibility and shows when the image fails to load.
Unordered lists use <ul> with <li> items - they render as bullet points.
Ordered lists use <ol> with <li> items - they render as numbered items.
Hint: In the game, to display an image you need the self-closing tag with a src attribute pointing to the image file.
key_points: <ul> for bullet lists, <ol> for numbered lists

game.question: How many items will this list display?

lessons.title: Forms & Semantic HTML
lessons.content: Collect user input with forms and structure pages with semantic tags
details: The <form> tag wraps form controls and has action (where to send data) and method (GET or POST) attributes.
Common input types: text, email, password, checkbox, radio, submit.
<label> links to an input using the for attribute matching the input's id.
Using semantic tags improves accessibility and helps search engines understand your page.
<button type='submit'> submits the form; <button type='button'> does not.
Hint: In the game, the correct input type for an email field is 'email' - it adds built-in browser validation for the @ symbol.
lessons.example_code:
<form action='/submit' method='POST'>
  <label for='email'>Email:</label>
  <input type='email' id='email' name='email'>
  <button type='submit'>Send</button>
</form>
key_points: <form action method> wraps all form controls
Semantic tags: header, nav, main, footer

lessons.title: Variables: var, let, const
lessons.content: Understand the three ways to declare variables in JavaScript
details: JavaScript has three variable keywords: var (old), let (block-scoped, reassignable), and const (block-scoped, fixed reference).
Use let when the value will change: let count = 0; count = 1;
Use const when the value should never be reassigned: const PI = 3.14;
Avoid var in modern JS - it has confusing function-scope behavior.
const must be initialized at declaration: const name = 'Alice'; - you cannot write just const name;
Hint: In the game you must declare a constant called MAX with value 100. Constants in JS use the keyword 'const'.
key_points: const for values that never change
let for values that can change
Prefer const by default, use let when needed

game.question: Declare a constant called MAX with value 100

lessons.title: Arrow Functions
lessons.content: Write concise functions using the modern arrow syntax
details: Arrow functions are a shorter syntax for writing functions, introduced in ES6.
Traditional: function add(a, b) { return a + b; }
Arrow syntax: const add = (a, b) => a + b;
If the function body is a single expression, the curly braces and return keyword can be omitted.
If there is only one parameter, the parentheses are optional: const double = x => x * 2;
Arrow functions do not have their own 'this' context.
Hint: In the game, the arrow function square(x) should return x multiplied by itself: x * x. Single-expression arrows omit return.
key_points: Single expression: braces and return optional

push() adds one or more elements to the end of an array.
pop() removes the last element from an array.
map() creates a new array by transforming every element with a function.
filter() creates a new array containing only elements that pass a test.
Check length with .length: fruits.length returns the count.

lessons.title: SELECT Queries
lessons.content: Retrieve data from database tables using SELECT statements
details: SQL (Structured Query Language) is used to interact with relational databases.
Basic syntax: SELECT column1, column2 FROM table_name;
SELECT * retrieves ALL columns from a table - the asterisk * means 'everything'.
Use WHERE to filter rows: SELECT * FROM users WHERE age > 18;
ORDER BY sorts results: ORDER BY name ASC (ascending) or DESC (descending).
LIMIT restricts the number of rows returned: LIMIT 10;
Hint: In the game, to retrieve ALL columns from the 'products' table, use the wildcard asterisk: SELECT * FROM products - the * selects every column.
lessons.example_code:
-- Get all users
SELECT * FROM users;

-- Get specific columns with filter
SELECT name, email FROM users
WHERE is_active = 1
ORDER BY name ASC
LIMIT 10;
key_points: ORDER BY sorts, LIMIT restricts count

lessons.title: INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE
lessons.content: Modify your database data with SQL's DML commands
details: INSERT adds new rows: INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES ('Alice', 'alice@ex.com');
UPDATE modifies existing rows: UPDATE users SET name='Bob' WHERE id=1;
DELETE removes rows: DELETE FROM users WHERE id=1;
ALWAYS use WHERE with UPDATE and DELETE - without it, ALL rows are modified or deleted!
INSERT can add multiple rows at once by separating value groups with commas.
Use transactions (BEGIN/COMMIT/ROLLBACK) to safely group multiple operations.
Hint: In the game, to change the email of the user with id=5, use the UPDATE command. Syntax: UPDATE table SET column='value' WHERE condition.

lessons.title: JOINs
lessons.content: Combine data from multiple tables using SQL JOIN clauses
details: JOIN combines rows from two or more tables based on a related column.
INNER JOIN returns only rows where the condition matches in BOTH tables.
LEFT JOIN returns all rows from the left table, and matching rows from the right (NULL if no match).
RIGHT JOIN is the reverse of LEFT JOIN.
FULL OUTER JOIN returns all rows from both tables.
Syntax: SELECT a.col, b.col FROM tableA a INNER JOIN tableB b ON a.id = b.a_id;
Hint: INNER JOIN is the most common join type - it returns only the rows that have matching values in BOTH tables. In the game, use INNER JOIN to combine the orders and customers tables.
lessons.example_code:
-- Get orders with customer names
SELECT orders.id, customers.name, orders.total
FROM orders
INNER JOIN customers
  ON orders.customer_id = customers.id
WHERE orders.total > 100;
key_points: INNER JOIN: only matching rows in both tables
LEFT JOIN: all left + matching right
Table aliases (a, b) keep queries readable

title: CSS & Styling

lessons.title: Selectors & Specificity
lessons.content: Target HTML elements precisely with CSS selectors
details: CSS selectors target HTML elements to apply styles.

Element selector: p { color: red; } targets all

tags.
Class selector: .highlight { color: blue; } targets elements with class='highlight'.
ID selector: #header { font-size: 24px; } targets the element with id='header'.
Specificity determines which rule wins when multiple rules target the same element.
Order of specificity (highest to lowest): inline styles > ID > class > element.
Hint: A class selector ALWAYS starts with a period/dot (.). To target elements with the class 'btn', write .btn { }. The dot is essential.

game.question: Write a CSS selector that targets elements with class 'btn'

lessons.title: Flexbox Layout
lessons.content: Arrange items horizontally and vertically with CSS Flexbox
details: Flexbox is a one-dimensional layout model for distributing space among items in a container.
Enable flexbox on the parent/container: display: flex;
flex-direction sets the main axis: row (horizontal, default) or column (vertical).
justify-content aligns items on the main axis: flex-start, center, flex-end, space-between, space-around.
align-items aligns items on the cross axis: flex-start, center, flex-end, stretch.
flex-wrap: wrap allows items to wrap to the next line when they overflow.
Hint: In the game, to activate flexbox layout on a container, you set the CSS property 'display' to 'flex'. The property name is 'display'.

game.question: Enable Flexbox on a container element

lessons.title: Responsive Design & Media Queries
lessons.content: Make your layouts adapt to any screen size using media queries
details: Responsive design means your website looks good on all devices - phones, tablets, desktops.
Media queries apply styles only when conditions (screen size, device type) are met.
max-width targets screens at or BELOW that width (desktop-first approach).
min-width targets screens at or ABOVE that width (mobile-first approach).
Hint: In the game, to apply styles ONLY when screen width is 768px or less, use max-width: 768px inside the @media rule. max-width means 'up to and including this width'.
